In the video, it explains how the chemical, resiniferatoxin (or RTX), is in fact the hottest chemical in the world. RTX is a chemical that activates heat-sensitive neurons that have a receptor called TRPV1. TRPV1 triggers pain brought about from fire when exposed to high temperatures or acid, so techanally when you eat spicy food, your brain thinks you’re getting burned. With this effect in place, RTX amplifies this, making it near to deadly. You would think this stuff coud only be made in a lab, but its actually found prominent in a cactus-like plant called Morocco. Better yet, scientists also intend to make this chemical useable in medicine. By the end of this video, I had learned that so called “spicy food” is just a chemical makeup which tricks your brain into thinking you’re on fire.

“It either activates the pain sensing neurons until they’re exhausted or they die”

I seem to have this bizarrely superhuman immunity to capsaicin. Like...Ghost Peppers, which have a Scoville unit of about 1 million...literally taste like sweet bell peppers to me...at least on my tongue. If it gets caught im my throat, I feel it. And my digestive tract certainly feels it the next day. XD

Another weird thing is when I eat hot peppers, I get all the other effects like the endorphin rush and sudden hot-flash sweat, despite not feeling the burn. This has lead me family to suggest I participate in hot pepper eating contests since it's very possible I could win on a national level.

A lethal dose of 10gram is really not that scary of a chemical. To eat 10g of capsaicin you would have to eat about 100g of Carolina reapers. Rtx is 1000x hotter than capsaicin.  To reach the equivalent heat of 10g rtx you would have to eat 100kg of reapers. Which, I’m pretty sure, constitutes a lethal dose. It’s almost comical to think that anyone could accidentally take in anywhere near that much rtx through food stuffs. To suggest that people’s lives would be in danger if rtx was used in hot sauce is misleading at best. At worst, it promotes bad science; the antithesis of what channel appears stand for

I'm don't add 👎unless something is pirated, highly offensive to me, or plain wrong and I can prove it. However, I will leave a comment. A 3.5 minute video with 1/3 of it taken up by an in content ad is really pushing it. I've unsubscribed from several channels that started consistently uploading sub-5 minute content with these long ads.
I don't mean to be overly negative, and I am all for SciShow monetizing wherever possible. I think the cliche ads from the dozen or so companies everyone does ads for, have long long overstayed their welcome. In my opinion the future on this platform is following Mr. Linus (Tech Tips and others (no affiliation)). That dude has it dialed. I'm not a fanboi. I don't watch half or more of his content, and I hate clickbait titles. However he has one thing perfectly on the mark. The future is definitely the ultra short and fresh in-content ads placed according to the CC's discretion, with the CC being highly cognizant of what they are plugging and putting their endorsement on. Linus' in content ads are almost comical, relevant, and effective. IMO, he's revisiting the early TV and Radio style ads and doing it well. Companies like SciShow really really need to recognize this new shift in marketing and follow suit IMO. These same ads are becoming very cringeworthy, even for someone that is very supportive about this kind of thing.
-Jake
